title: Ticket #1091: undo bad rebase of V7_4-branch
description:
The changes documented below involve versions of Condor that were never released. Customers do not need to worry about them.

An incorrect rebase of V7_4-branch caused it to be updated to the head of the master. The following command was likely responsible: 

# bad command
git rebase origin V7_4-branch
# what was intended
git rebase origin/V7_4-branch

The sha1 of V7_4-branch before the bad rebase was c49eb913f7c8aee2b9fb97bd63655806ae759c80. The sha1 of V7_4-branch after the bad rebase was 80fc0a87a790657756aed97dd3d4bdc852e50081, which was incorrectly believed to be a bad merge into V7_4-branch. In #1084, 80fc0a back to but not including 584e2bb18f4e038066e44b53cddd9945e0b9dbbb was surgically removed, but this still left a bunch of undesired things from the master branch in V7_4-branch.

The bad rebase has been undone, but it has ramifications for anyone working with our git repository.

All developers will need to check to make sure they don't have the bad rebase lurking in their repositories. If you haven't done a "git pull" or fetch since December 20th, you're probably okay, but check anyway.

To check, on any local branch you have that is based on V7_4-branch, do the following, repleacing V7_4-branch with your local branch name.

  1. Check if you have the bad rebase on the branch: 
    git rev-list V7_4-branch | grep c36ba64711f227570c5d5d06924a558bed85e2af
  2. Check the output and return code ("echo $?") of the previous command:
    • If there is no output and a non-zero return code, all is well. This branch is safe. Go back to the start and repeat for other branches based on V7_4-branch. If you're out of branches, you're done!
    • If the return code is 0 and the output is "c36ba64711f227570c5d5d06924a558bed85e2af", then you have the bad rebase. If this is the case, you must destroy and recreate the branch, otherwise you could reinfect the central repository. Continue:
  3. You'll need to delete your infected V7_4-branch and recreate it. Do you have committed changes to V7_4-branch that you haven't pushed?
    • No un-pushed changes: Just run the following to delete and recreate the local branch: 
      git checkout master
git branch -D V7_4-branch
git branch V7_4-branch origin/V7_4-branch
    • Un-pushed changes: You will want to store your good changes away and reapply them. Be careful to not accidentally drag in the bad merge! You can not use git stash for this, as git stash will just stash away the bad merge. You can do this by hand, or you can use "git format-patch" and "git am" to store them away and re-apply them. Use "gitk" or similar to find the ranges of SHAs that contain your changes. Be sure to not include c36ba64711f227570c5d5d06924a558bed85e2af in the range! If you have multiple ranges, simply call "git format-patch" repeatedly, appending to the same file. Once you have your ranges, use the following, or something similar: 
      git format-patch --stdout EARLIEST_GOOD_SHA1..CURRENT_GOOD_SHA1 > v7.4-rescue
git checkout master
git branch -D V7_4-branch
git branch V7_4-branch origin/V7_4-branch
git checkout V7_4-branch
git am v7.4-rescue

How it was fixed

# Save good work on V7_4-branch.
git format-patch --stdout 584e2bb18f4e038066e44b53cddd9945e0b9dbbb..V7_4-branch > ~/v7.4-rescue

# Back V7_4-branch to the commit immediately before the bad rebase happened.
git reset --hard c49eb913f7c8aee2b9fb97bd63655806ae759c80

# Reapply the good work
git am v7.4-rescue

# Patches 1, 6, and 7 did not apply cleanly so I had to edit the files
# manually, add them to the index, and run git am --resolved

# Delete upstream version
git push origin :V7_4-branch
# Push corrected version
git push origin +V7_4-branch

# Merge to the master
# Since all of the V7_4 work was already merged to the master
# and since there were some conflicts in how the patches were
# reapplied to V7_4, I used the 'ours' merge strategy
# so the master is untouched by the merge
git checkout master
git merge -s ours V7_4-branch
creator: danb
